scenarios.name: Party Observation
scenarios.context: You're at a house party with about 30-40 people. Music is loud, people are drinking and dancing. You notice someone who appears very intoxicated - unsteady on their feet, slurred speech - being led upstairs by someone they seem to have just met. Your friends are nearby in the living room.

A.text: Directly approach and check if the intoxicated person is okay
A.feedback: Direct intervention can be effective! You showed courage in speaking up. Key phrases that work: 'Hey, I think your friends are looking for you.' This respected everyone's dignity while creating a pause.

B.text: Create a distraction (spill drink, fake urgent call)
B.feedback: Distraction is great when you're uncomfortable with direct confrontation. You created a physical barrier and gave time for reconsideration. Low-risk approach that still interrupts the situation.

C.text: Get friends or the party host to help intervene
C.feedback: Getting help is smart! Multiple people are more effective and less threatening. Safety in numbers gives you more options and social proof makes concerns harder to dismiss.

D.text: Observe for a moment to assess the situation better
D.feedback: Observation can be useful but should be BRIEF. The window for easy intervention closes quickly. Once they're in a private space, intervention becomes more difficult. Trust your instincts and act quickly.

decision_points.prompt: The person is now safe with you and your friends. They're sitting down, drinking water. What's your next step?

A.text: Help them get home safely (call friend/rideshare)
A.feedback: Excellent follow-through! Intervention doesn't stop at the first action. Following through ensures the person is actually safe, not just away from immediate danger.

B.text: Stay with them until they feel better
B.feedback: Good choice! Staying with someone vulnerable shows care and ensures they're not left alone. This is part of complete bystander intervention.

C.feedback: Connecting them with their support network is helpful. Make sure their friends are trustworthy and sober enough to help.

scenarios.name: Friend Disclosure
scenarios.context: A close friend pulls you aside at lunch and shares that something happened at a party last weekend. They seem upset and uncertain about what to do. They haven't told anyone else yet.

A.text: Listen without judgment and validate their feelings
A.feedback: Excellent response. Listening and validating is the most important first step. Let them tell their story at their own pace without interrupting or asking for details.

B.text: Ask what they need right now and offer support
B.feedback: Good! Centering their needs respects their autonomy. Every survivor's needs are different - some want resources, others just need someone to listen.

C.feedback: While reporting is an option, jumping straight to this can feel overwhelming. It's better to listen first, then ask what THEY want to do. Support their choice.

D.text: Share information about counseling and support services
D.feedback: Providing resource information is helpful! Make sure to present it as options, not requirements. They decide if and when they're ready.

decision_points.prompt: Your friend says they're not ready to report but might want to talk to a counselor. What do you do?

A.text: Offer to go with them to the counseling center
A.feedback: Perfect! Offering to accompany them shows support without pressure. Sometimes having someone there makes it easier to take that first step.

B.text: Give them the counseling center's contact info and check in later
B.feedback: Good balance of providing information and respecting their timeline. Following up shows you care and are available when they're ready.

C.text: Respect their timeline and let them know you're here whenever they need
C.feedback: Excellent! Respecting their pace is crucial. Healing isn't linear, and they need to feel in control of their own process.

scenarios.name: Group Chat
scenarios.context: Your friend group chat has someone sharing inappropriate photos and making sexual comments about another student without their knowledge. Multiple people are laughing and adding to it.

A.text: Speak up in the group chat
A.feedback: Bold move! Speaking up publicly can shift group norms. Example: 'This doesn't feel right. Would you want people sharing your photos like this?' It might feel awkward but can stop harmful behavior.

B.feedback: Good strategy! Private messages can be effective without public confrontation. You can explain why the behavior is harmful without embarrassing them in front of others.

C.text: Leave the chat and explain why
C.feedback: Setting a boundary! Leaving and stating your reason sends a message about what behavior you accept. It may prompt others to reconsider too.

D.text: Report to platform admins or authorities
D.feedback: Reporting is appropriate when someone's privacy or safety is violated. Many platforms have policies against sharing intimate images without consent.

scenarios.name: Consent Conversation
scenarios.context: At a small gathering, you overhear someone bragging about 'wearing down' their date until they agreed to hook up. Others in the group are laughing uncomfortably.

A.text: Speak up in the moment about what consent means
A.feedback: Brave! Educating in the moment can be powerful. Example: 'That's not consent - pressuring someone isn't the same as them freely agreeing.' You might get pushback but you plant seeds.

B.text: Pull them aside later for a private conversation
B.feedback: Strategic approach! Private conversations allow for deeper discussion without defensiveness. You can explain why coercion isn't consent without public shame.

C.text: Change the subject and check in with uncomfortable people
C.feedback: Good awareness! Others may be triggered or uncomfortable. Checking in shows care, though the harmful behavior still needs addressing.

D.text: Report the concerning statement to campus authorities
D.feedback: If the behavior described sounds like assault, reporting is appropriate. Many campuses have anonymous reporting options for concerning behavior.

scenarios.name: Campus Response
scenarios.context: You witnessed something concerning last night and want to do something about it, but you're unsure what options you have and what the consequences might be.

A.feedback: Smart! Many campuses have anonymous reporting hotlines. This lets you report concerning behavior without revealing your identity, and authorities can monitor patterns.

B.text: Talk to a confidential resource (counselor, chaplain)
B.feedback: Excellent! Confidential resources can help you process what you saw and explore options WITHOUT triggering mandatory reporting. They can guide you through choices.

C.feedback: Good! Understanding the formal process helps you make informed decisions. Title IX offices can explain options without requiring you to file a formal report immediately.

D.text: Talk to the person you're concerned about first
D.feedback: Thoughtful! If you witnessed something happen to someone, checking in with them respects their autonomy. Ask what THEY want, don't assume. Support their choices.
